nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: You’re in a small meeting room. The mediator sits between you and your co-parent. This is the first time you’re trying to put your new parenting schedule into clear written agreements.

choices.label: Start with the child’s needs first.
choices.text: You say: “Before anything else, I’d like us to focus on what keeps our child feeling safe and stable.”

choices.label: Jump straight into your frustrations.
choices.text: You say: “I’m still upset about how the last handover went. We can’t keep doing it like that.”

choices.label: Stay very quiet and let the mediator lead.
choices.text: You sit back and say little, letting the mediator start the conversation.

nodes.speaker: Mediator
nodes.text: The mediator nods and summarizes: “Let’s choose one concrete area for today: drop-offs and pick-ups. What would a realistic, child-friendly routine look like for both of you?”

choices.label: Propose a clear, simple routine.
choices.text: You suggest: “Same days every week, same time and same place — so our child always knows what to expect.”

choices.label: Ask for maximum flexibility.
choices.text: You say: “My work shifts change, so I need us to stay flexible and adjust week by week.”

choices.label: Focus on what your ex is doing wrong.
choices.text: You respond: “Honestly, the problem is that you’re always late. Until that changes, no schedule will work.”

nodes.speaker: Ex-Partner
nodes.text: Your co-parent shifts in their chair. They look tired, defensive, and a little sad.

choices.label: Acknowledge something they’re doing well.
choices.text: You add: “I know you care about being there for our child. I see how much effort you put in, even when we disagree.”

choices.label: Stay purely factual and distant.
choices.text: You stick to logistics only: times, locations, and backup plans — nothing personal, nothing emotional.

choices.label: Let your anger speak for you.
choices.text: You say: “You say you care, but your actions don’t match. I’m tired of cleaning up the mess.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: By the end of the session, some things are still unresolved — that’s normal. But there is at least the outline of a plan, and a clearer sense of what helps the child feel safe.

choices.label: Reflect and return to menu.
choices.text: You mentally note which parts of the conversation calmed things — and which parts spiked the tension.
